prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) = cos A cos B – sin A sin B (cosine addition formula)
dependent_name: cos 2A = cos^2 A – sin^2 A (double-angle cosine formula)
explanation: Setting B = A in the cosine addition formula yields the double-angle formula for cosine directly (cos 2A = cos(A+A)).

prerequisite_name: sin(A+B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B (sine addition formula)
dependent_name: sin 2A = 2 sin A cos A (double-angle sine formula)
explanation: Setting B = A in the sine addition formula gives sin 2A = sin(A+A) = 2 sin A cos A.

prerequisite_name: sin(A+B) and cos(A+B) (sine and cosine addition formulae)
dependent_name: tan(A+B) = (tan A + tan B) / (1 – tan A tan B) (tangent addition formula)
explanation: The tangent addition formula is derived by taking sin(A+B)/cos(A+B), so the sine and cosine addition formulae are directly needed.

prerequisite_name: tan(A+B) = (tan A + tan B) / (1 – tan A tan B) (tangent addition formula)
dependent_name: tan 2A (double-angle tangent formula)
explanation: The double-angle tangent formula is obtained by setting B = A in the tangent addition formula (tan 2A = tan(A+A)).

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A–B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B) + cos(A–B) (product-to-sum cosine identity)
explanation: Adding the cosine addition and subtraction formulae yields the product-to-sum identity 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B)+cos(A–B).

prerequisite_name: product-to-sum identities (e.g., 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B) + cos(A–B))
dependent_name: sum-to-product identities (e.g., cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2))
explanation: Sum-to-product formulae are obtained by algebraic manipulation of product-to-sum relations (or vice versa); the product-to-sum identities listed earlier are used to derive the sum-to-product forms.

prerequisite_name: cos^2 A + sin^2 A = 1 (Pythagorean identity)
dependent_name: cos^2 A = 1/2 (1 + cos 2A) and sin^2 A = 1/2 (1 – cos 2A) (power-reduction identities)
explanation: The power-reduction formulae are derived by combining the Pythagorean identity with the double-angle cosine identity to express squared sine and cosine in terms of cos 2A.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A–B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: 2 sin A sin B = cos(A–B) – cos(A+B) (product-to-sum sine identity)
explanation: Subtracting the cosine addition and subtraction formulae gives the product-to-sum identity for 2 sin A sin B = cos(A–B) – cos(A+B), as listed.

prerequisite_name: sin(A–B) and cos(A–B) (sine and cosine subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: tan(A–B) = (tan A – tan B) / (1 + tan A tan B) (tangent subtraction formula)
explanation: The tangent subtraction formula follows from tan(A–B) = sin(A–B)/cos(A–B), so the sine and cosine subtraction formulae are directly required.

prerequisite_name: sin(A–B) and cos(A–B) (sine and cosine subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: 2 sin A sin B = cos(A–B) – cos(A+B) (product-to-sum sine identity)
explanation: The product-to-sum sine identity is derived by combining the sine and cosine addition/subtraction formulas (specifically forming cos(A–B) – cos(A+B)).

prerequisite_name: cos 2A = cos^2 A – sin^2 A (double-angle cosine formula)
dependent_name: cos^2 A = 1/2 (1 + cos 2A) and sin^2 A = 1/2 (1 – cos 2A) (power-reduction identities)
explanation: Rearranging the double-angle cosine identity and using the Pythagorean identity yields the power-reduction formulas for cos^2 A and sin^2 A.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A–B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: sum-to-product identities (e.g., cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2))
explanation: Sum-to-product identities are derived from the addition and subtraction formulas by appropriate substitution and algebraic manipulation.

prerequisite_name: sin(A+B) and cos(A+B) (sine and cosine addition formulae)
dependent_name: tan(A+B) = (tan A + tan B) / (1 − tan A tan B) (tangent addition formula)
explanation: The tangent addition formula is derived by dividing the sine addition formula by the cosine addition formula (tan(A+B)=sin(A+B)/cos(A+B)). The text explicitly notes this derivation.

prerequisite_name: tan(A+B) = (tan A + tan B)/(1 − tan A tan B) (tangent addition formula)
dependent_name: tan 2A (double-angle tangent formula)
explanation: The double-angle tangent formula follows by setting B = A in the tangent addition formula (tan(2A)=tan(A+A)). This is a direct logical step from the addition formula.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A−B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B) + cos(A−B) (product-to-sum cosine identity)
explanation: The product-to-sum cosine identity is obtained by combining the cosine addition and subtraction formulae. The text presents the addition/subtraction formulae and the product-to-sum identities in the same formula set and derivations.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A−B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: 2 sin A sin B = cos(A−B) − cos(A+B) (product-to-sum sine identity)
explanation: The product-to-sum sine identity is derived from the cosine addition/subtraction identities (by appropriate combination). The text includes these cosine addition/subtraction formulae and the product-to-sum identities in the same development.

prerequisite_name: cos^2 A + sin^2 A = 1 (Pythagorean identity)
dependent_name: cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1 (alternate double-angle cosine form)
explanation: Starting from cos 2A = cos^2 A − sin^2 A and substituting sin^2 A = 1 − cos^2 A (the Pythagorean identity) yields cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1. The text shows this manipulation explicitly when deriving double-angle forms.

prerequisite_name: cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1 (double-angle cosine formula)
dependent_name: cos^2 A = 1/2 (1 + cos 2A) and sin^2 A = 1/2 (1 − cos 2A) (power-reduction identities)
explanation: Rearranging the double-angle cosine formula gives the power-reduction identities for cos^2 A; using cos^2+sin^2=1 yields the sin^2 identity. The text derives these power-reduction forms from the double-angle formula.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) (cosine addition formula)
dependent_name: cos(A−B) (cosine subtraction formula)
explanation: The subtraction formula is obtained from the addition formula by replacing B with −B (cos(A−B)=cos(A+(-B))). The text uses this symmetry (noting cos(−θ)=cos θ) in deriving subtraction forms.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A−B) (addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: sum-to-product identities (e.g., cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A−B)/2))
explanation: Sum-to-product identities are obtained by manipulating addition/subtraction formulae (or via product-to-sum identities). The text groups these identities together in its formulae/tables and uses addition/subtraction formulae to derive related identities.

prerequisite_name: cos 2A = cos^2 A – sin^2 A (double-angle cosine formula)
dependent_name: cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1 (alternate double-angle cosine form)
explanation: Rewriting cos^2 A − sin^2 A using the Pythagorean identity (sin^2 A = 1 − cos^2 A) gives cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1, so the standard double-angle form together with the Pythagorean identity leads to the alternate form.

prerequisite_name: cos 2A = cos^2 A – sin^2 A (double-angle cosine formula)
dependent_name: cos^2 A = 1/2 (1 + cos 2A) and sin^2 A = 1/2 (1 − cos 2A) (power-reduction identities)
explanation: Algebraic rearrangement of the double-angle formula for cos 2A produces expressions for cos^2 A and sin^2 A in terms of cos 2A (power-reduction), so the double-angle cosine identity is required.

prerequisite_name: sin(A−B) and cos(A−B) (sine and cosine subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: tan(A−B) = (tan A – tan B) / (1 + tan A tan B) (tangent subtraction formula)
explanation: The tangent subtraction formula is derived by dividing the sine subtraction formula by the cosine subtraction formula (tan(A−B)=sin(A−B)/cos(A−B)), so knowledge of those subtraction formulae is needed.

prerequisite_name: sin 2A = 2 sin A cos A and cos 2A = cos^2 A – sin^2 A (double-angle sine and cosine formulae)
dependent_name: tan 2A (double-angle tangent formula)
explanation: The double-angle tangent formula is obtained by taking tan(2A)=sin(2A)/cos(2A), so the double-angle sine and cosine identities are directly required.

prerequisite_name: cos(A+B) and cos(A−B) (cosine addition and subtraction formulae)
dependent_name: sum-to-product identities (e.g., cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A−B)/2))
explanation: Sum-to-product identities are derived by algebraic manipulation of addition/subtraction formulas (or product-to-sum identities) and require the addition/subtraction formulae as a basis.

prerequisite_name: product-to-sum identities (e.g., 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B) + cos(A−B))
dependent_name: sum-to-product identities (e.g., cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A−B)/2))
explanation: Sum-to-product formulas are algebraic rearrangements of product-to-sum (and vice versa); one set can be derived from the other by simple substitution and algebra.

prerequisite_name: cos 2A = 2 cos^2 A − 1 (alternate double-angle cosine form)
dependent_name: cos^2 A = 1/2 (1 + cos 2A) and sin^2 A = 1/2 (1 – cos 2A) (power-reduction identities)
explanation: Rearranging the double-angle cosine formula gives cos^2 A = (1 + cos 2A)/2; using cos^2 + sin^2 = 1 yields the corresponding identity for sin^2 A.
